title: Europe Today: Interview with Varoufakis; EU leaders to debate eurobonds in informal summit
content: Tune in to Euronews' new flagship morning programme at 8 am Brussels time. In just 20 minutes, we bring you up to speed on the biggest news of the day.

title: How Europe’s defence push is testing existing arms-export rules
content: As world leaders gather at the 2026 Munich Security Conference, Europe’s defence push is in focus, but cracks in its arms-export system are showing. Despite strict EU rules, loopholes still funnel weapons to high-risk destinations.

title: EU summit: Leaders meet to search for bold ways to revive stagnant economy
content: Thursday's summit on competitiveness brings the 27 EU leaders together at the Alden Biesen castle in eastern Belgium.

title: Choose to federalise or 'we can disband the euro,' Varoufakis tells Euronews
content: The former Greek finance minister and economist told Euronews flagship morning show Europe Today that the EU is stuck between federation and disbanding, blaming weak fiscal and investment pillars for Europe’s disintegration.

title: Newsletter: Avoiding the 'slow agony' of EU economic decline
content: How to restore Europe's economic edge in a world of aggressive competition? It's the question on the table as EU leaders gather for a retreat in the Belgian countryside later today.

title: Who decides who belongs in Europe? The migration debate returns
content: In this week’s episode of The Ring, MEPs Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D) and Tomas Tobé (EPP) engage in a deep debate over how Europe should manage migration - from applying the “safe third country” concept to Spain’s large-scale regularisation plan.

title: EU approves €38bn in first defence investments under €150bn SAFE scheme
content: Three member states that have asked for funding under SAFE have yet to have their national plans greenlit by the European Commission, the first of two required steps.

title: NATO rejects claim ‘Arctic Sentry’ is a rebrand to appease Trump
content: A NATO military officer argued that Arctic Sentry shows the alliance is "trying to get ahead" of threats in the region.

title: France's assisted dying bill: Claims vs facts
content: France is engaged in a political debate over a controversial proposal to create a legal right to medically-assisted dying. One of the key concerns is the eligibility criteria, sparking a number of claims about how far the proposed law could go.

title: Industry bosses call on EU leaders for 'urgent and bold' action to cut energy prices
content: The plea comes ahead of an informal summit in Alden Biesen on Thursday, when leaders will discuss the bloc's competitiveness and ways to revitalise the economy, particularly for energy-intensive sectors.

title: European Parliament's political groups agree EU-US trade deal
content: Representatives of the Parliament's groups have agreed on the conditions for applying the controversial agreement. After the formal vote, negotiations with EU member states will move towards a final text.

title: Hungary's Tisza Party breaks ranks with EPP in bid to counter Brussels puppet claims
content: Hungary's Tisza Party has defied the EPP group's stance three times in a month, drawing sanctions and internal concern, but ahead of Hungary's April elections, taking a stand could help counter Viktor Orbán's claims the party serves Brussels and not the national interest.

title: European Parliament clears way for transferring asylum seekers to unrelated countries
content: A legislative change approved by the European Parliament will enable EU states to send asylum seekers to countries with which they have no existing link.

title: Should the EU speak directly with Putin? Leaders agree to disagree – for now
content: The idea of re-engaging with the Kremlin as part of the peace talks to end the war in Ukraine has sharply split EU countries, with some calling for a special envoy and others insisting that Russia make concessions first.

title: 'European preference is a risk to healthy supply chains,' EU industries tell Euronews
content: As EU leaders put “Made in Europe” on their agenda at Thursday’s informal summit, industries across the bloc are warning that European preference regulations could upend global supply chains – and questioning how such a policy would work in practice.

title: Von der Leyen pitches two-speed Europe ahead of Draghi crunch summit
content: Commission President says bloc should consider cooperation among smaller groups of countries if unanimity is not possible to push through economic agenda. Draghi called for 'pragmatic federalism' ahead of crunch summit.

title: Hungarian election campaign enters hot phase with Ukraine, the EU and Trump in focus
content: With two months until Hungary's April election, Prime Minister Viktor Orbán has intensified his anti-Ukraine rhetoric, while leading challenger Péter Magyar promises to curb corruption and tax relief for low earners.

title: Tehran 'will continue to massacre people' if not stopped, Iranian chess grandmaster tells Euronews
content: In an interview for Euronews' flagship morning show Europe Today, Iranian chess grandmaster Mitra Hejazipour urged international action over Iran’s deadly protest crackdown, backed Reza Pahlavi and warned US-Iran talks are a dead end.

title: Proposed EU long-term agriculture budget has monitoring flaws, Court of Auditors warns
content: The European Court of Auditors said on Monday that the upcoming long-term EU agriculture budget raises concerns about the traceability of funds.

title: Why the EU wants to end the price cap on Russian oil and move to the next stage
content: The 20th package of EU sanctions against Moscow foresees a blanket ban on maritime services. If approved, it would discard the price cap on Russian oil that Western allies have applied since 2022.

title: NATO ministers insist Ukraine is top priority following launch of Arctic activity
content: The row over Greenland last month had sparked fears the 70-year-old military alliance could implode, but allies now appear to be getting back to business as usual.

title: Hungary's Péter Magyar calls out 'Russian-style' sex tape threat as campaign turns ugly
content: The opposition leader, who is leading the polls ahead of April's elections, says Viktor Orbán's party is orchestrating a smear campaign with secretly recorded intimate videos.

title: How many Europeans are insuring their property against climate disasters?
content: Worries are sky high following the latest weather bombs in Spain, Portugal and Italy.

title: France set to clash with Germany and Italy as EU leaders seek economic boost
content: Paris is facing a Berlin-Rome axis in the debate over how to revive the EU economy. From eurobonds to a European preference and the Mercosur trade deal, competing visions are set to collide when the bloc’s 27 leaders meet on Thursday.

title: European preference is 'necessary' but a 'fine line to walk', warns von der Leyen
content: The debate on "Made in Europe" will be at the centre of the discussions that EU leaders will have during an informal summit on Thursday.

title: EU unveils strategy to shield bloc from malicious drones
content: The European Commission's new strategy includes new investments in technological development to integrate surveillance capacity.

title: Orbán's rivals promise an end to Hungary's 'inflated vetoes' of EU policy
content: Hungary's opposition Tisza Party boasts a serious track record of experience – including quite a lot of work for previous Orbán governments. What can the world expect from them?

title: Watch the video: What is von der Leyen's letter to all 27 EU leaders actually about?
content: In her letter, von der Leyen is essentially saying: if we cannot agree now as 27, let us break the taboo and move forward in smaller groups.

title: 'EU-US trade deal is a total capitulation to Trump,' MEP Bricmont says
content: In an interview with Euronews' morning show Europe Today, Greens/EFA group MEP Saskia Bricmont said the trade agreement between the EU and the United States as a "total capitulation", calling for more investments and decoupling from Washington.

title: Newsletter: How to fix Europe’s competitiveness problem?
content: Also in this newsletter: US expected to withdraw only a limited amount of troops from NATO territory; why EU leaders agree to disagree on who should speak to Putin; and how Hungary's Tisza party is breaking ranks with the EPP to shake off the "Brussels puppet" label.

title: European leaders meet industry heavyweights in power shift for business
content: European leaders are meeting industry bosses in Antwerp before an informal summit focused on competitiveness. Rome and Berlin push to cut bureaucracy, while Paris calls for Made in Europe preference.

title: Europe’s gun industry: From regulation to global exports
content: Europe has some of the world’s strictest gun regulations, yet it is also one of the largest producers and exporters of firearms. How does the EU regulate this industry? Watch the video.

title: Europe Today: Macron calls for more EU joint debt; Merz pushes back
content: Tune in to Euronews' new flagship morning programme at 8 am Brussels time. In just 20 minutes, we bring you up to speed on the biggest news of the day.

title: No gun culture, big gun industry: the EU’s quiet arms economy
content: Europe doesn’t have a strong “gun culture,” but maintains strict regulations. Still, as a major global producer and exporter of weapons, the regulation of ownership, licensing and enforcement remains the responsibility of individual EU countries.

title: US expected to reassure allies over limiting NATO troop withdrawal
content: The US is expected to commit to limiting the number of troops it will withdraw from NATO territory at a meeting of defence ministers Thursday. NATO is also due to announce plans for Arctic Sentry military mission to the High North in response to threats from Russia and China.

title: EU leaders grapple with how to build and finance a competitive Europe
content: EU leaders want to turn Europe into a competitive economic powerhouse with a strong single market, but they must agree on how to build and finance it. These questions will be at the heart of an informal summit on Thursday.

title: As challenges mount, a two-speed Europe emerges as a way out
content: The notion of a two-speed Europe has come to the fore as leaders search for groundbreaking solutions to revive the stagnant economy.

title: ArcelorMittal invests €1.3 billion to produce 'green steel' at its Dunkirk plant
content: In the presence of French President Emmanuel Macron, the steelmaker confirmed the construction of its largest electric furnace in Europe at its Dunkirk plant in northern France.

title: EU remains least corrupt but anti-graft progress stalls, report warns
content: The EU remains the least corrupt region but has stalled on reforms, with Hungary and Bulgaria worst, the Nordics best, and watchdogs warning of rising risks.

title: Rise of antisemitism: These are the EU countries reporting the most hostilities
content: Hostility in public spaces, antisemitic graffiti, and online antisemitism are the most frequently cited forms of antagonism.

title: Watch the video: The Bad Bunny Show — what does it sound like to be American?
content: Why is everyone in Europe talking about Bad Bunny? Short answer: because he made history.

title: 'EU countries should find resources without joint debt,' MEP Terras tells Euronews
content: In an interview with Euronews' flagship morning show Europe Today, EPP group's prominent MEP Riho Terras, said that EU member states should refrain from issuing common debt in order to finance their defence spending.

title: Newsletter: EU leaders raise the stakes ahead of talks on economic revival
content: Also in this newsletter: EU officials express reservations over Spain's decision to regularise undocumented migrants, and why the EU wants to end the price cap on Russian oil.

title: Europe Today: Von der Leyen calls on EU leaders to get ready for a multi-speed Europe
content: Tune in to Euronews' new flagship morning programme at 8 am Brussels time. In just 20 minutes, we bring you up to speed on the biggest news of the day.

title: Exclusive: EU Commission balks at Sánchez’s regularisation of undocumented migrants
content: The decision by the Spanish government to provide legal status to about half a million undocumented migrants has raised severe disapproval in Brussels, according to officials who spoke with Euronews on condition of anonymity.

title: European Parliament to 'test' support for digital euro
content: The European Parliament will vote on a report on the annual work of the European Central Bank, which includes a passage in support of the digital euro. The vote will take place on Tuesday.

title: From afterthought to asset: How NATO allies are reimagining their reserve forces
content: For governments, reservists come with three key benefits: they create mass, carry skills that can be difficult to find in the military, and build a bridge to civilian society. The goal? Boosting resilience.

title: Which EU countries could reverse their nuclear energy phaseouts?
content: Governments in Belgium and Italy are trying to lay out plans for a nuclear comeback, while calls to reverse Spain's phaseout remain stark.

title: France launches Orion 26, its biggest military drill since the Cold War
content: Orion 26 mobilises 12,500 troops, 25 ships and 140 aircraft as France and 24 allies rehearse high‑intensity warfare in Europe amid growing Russian threats.

title: Israeli policy in West Bank 'close to ethnic cleansing', says Ehud Olmert
content: The former Israeli premier decried his country's actions and policy in the West Bank just as the Israeli government announced radical plans to exert control of even more Palestinian territory.
